importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The incident occurred on October 19, 2025, and was reported as happening early Monday morning, marking a significant aviation safety event at Hong Kong International Airport.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred around 3:50 a.m. local time during the early morning hours, which is when the aircraft was landing from Dubai and skidded off the runway.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two airport staff in a patrol vehicle it struck.
The Boeing aircraft broke in two upon impact, with the tail section snapped off and significant damage to the front section below the cockpit.
The four crew members on board were treated for injuries but are confirmed to be safe; no cargo was on board.
The aircraft did not send any distress signals during approach, indicating a possible failure in handling or navigation.
The airport suspended operations on the north runway for safety and recovery efforts, though two other runways remained operational, ensuring minimal disruption to over 1,000 daily flights.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major carriers.
This incident highlights ongoing aviation safety concerns despite Hong Kong International Airport’s historically low fatality rates in aviation accidents.
In 1999, a previous major crash at the airport during a typhoon caused injuries to over 200 people, underscoring the airport’s challenging location and history of aviation incidents.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines, flying under an Emirates flight number, skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) around 3:50 a.m. local time on October 19, 2025, after landing from Dubai. The aircraft broke in two upon impact and collided with a security patrol vehicle, killing two occupants. The plane was left partially submerged, with significant damage to its front and tail sections. All four crew members were injured and transported to hospitals; no cargo was on board. The aircraft did not emit distress signals during approach, and the airport suspended operations on the north runway while emergency crews, including over 200 personnel, responded. Two other runways remained operational, minimizing disruption to over 1,000 daily flights. This incident, though rare in Hong Kong’s history of aviation safety, adds to the airport’s legacy of difficult landing conditions and past accidents, such as the 1999 China Airlines crash during a typhoon.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
